strengths: Basic arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division)
Understanding of place value and number sense
Ability to solve single-step word problems with familiar contexts
Comfortable with visualizing problems using diagrams
challenges: Struggles with multi-step word problems requiring multiple operations
Difficulty in identifying relevant information in word problems
Tends to rush calculations, leading to minor computational errors
Limited familiarity with fractions and decimals in applied contexts

learning_preferences: Benefits from worked examples before independent practice
Understands better when problems are framed in real-life scenarios (e.g., shopping, cooking)
problem_solving_approach: Attempts to break problems into smaller parts
Sometimes misinterprets problem wording, leading to incorrect operations
Needs prompting to check work systematically

motivators: Likes explanations with visual aids (diagrams, number lines)
Prefers interactive discussions over passive reading
demotivators: Frustrated by lengthy or complex instructions
Dislikes abstract problems without clear real-world relevance

notes: Alex benefits from scaffolding strategies when solving multi-step problems.
Providing guiding questions helps Alex focus on relevant details in word problems.
Encouraging Alex to verbalize thought processes improves problem comprehension.
